title: Queensland government partners with Johnson & Johnson to lure medical tech firms
text:
The Queensland government's Advance Queensland package of initiatives announced in the budget, and is aimed at encouraging healthcare technology companies to base themselves there. iStock Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Yolanda Redrup Multinational healthcare product company Johnson & Johnson is launching a $100,000 contest for medical tech startups, as part of a Queensland government plan to entice life sciences businesses to the Sunshine State..
The competition is part of the state government's Advance Queensland package of initiatives announced in the budget, and is aimed at encouraging healthcare technology companies to base themselves there.
Chief executive of Johnson & Johnson's pharmaceutical company Janssen Australia and New Zealand, Chris Hourigan, said Queensland had a good reputation for research, but the commercialisation of ideas had historically been a struggle.
"There is already a strong life sciences community, but the big gap is in commercialisation," Mr Hourigan said.
Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said global startups could also apply if they were willing to do their research in Queensland. Picking winners Three startups across the categories will be awarded $100,000 each as part of the Johnson & Johnson Innovation Quick Fire Challenge, on the condition that they do at least part of the research and development for the product within Queensland.
Johnson & Johnson Innovation Asia Pacific and other company executives will be on the selection committee and will work with the startups on their pitches prior to the main event, and serve as mentors to the selected businesses.
Janssen Australia and New Zealand managing director Chris Hourigan said the Australia was well known for its medical research, but struggled with commercialising ideas. Supplied Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said global startups could also apply if they were willing to do their research in Queensland.
"This is a global prize so we are looking for great ideas from across the world," she said.
"It is part of the $180 million Advance Queensland initiative to create jobs now and for the future, drive productivity improvements, harness innovation and translate some of our great ideas into real economic outcomes for Queenslanders."
Taking on Melbourne Melbourne is renowned as being the medical tech hub of Australia, home to more than 40 per cent of ASX-listed life sciences companies, but this push could attract more businesses to Queensland.
But managing director of pharmaceutical drug company IDT Australia, Paul MacLeman told The Australian Financial Review last month that Brisbane had already tried and failed to create a similar community .
"Melbourne's network and critical mass of medical institutions in the centre of the city was something that Brisbane couldn't match," he said.
Johnson & Johnson has a number of projects with Queensland universities. Through a partnership with James Cook University it is looking into whether or not proteins in hookworms can treat inflammatory bowel diseases like crohn's and ulcerative colitis.
It is also collaborating with the University of Queensland to developed more targeted pain relief using spider venom.
Mr Hourigan said Australia needed to go beyond being "one big mine".
"We have to be a knowledge-based economy," he said.
"The science is good, but we're not harnessing its full potential yet. We could be a centre of excellence around the world."
